cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about July 16
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about August 9.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said July 30
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said Aug 13
The summer fares are nett but passengers travelling at these rates and returning within 6 months at the winter rate, will obtain an abatement of 20 % off the the first and second class winter rate..
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, will leave Suez about August 1st.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 7,160 tons, will leave Port Said about August 6th.
May 26th-September 30th inclusive
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £8.0.0 ; London £12.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangoon £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.
S.S. Oamanieh, Wednesday 4 p.m. July 17,31, August 14 and 28
S.S. Ismallia Wednsdat 4 p.m. July 10,24, August 7 and 21

The fast steamers, Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA and continuing on alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suze alternately on Wednsdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

p.hi: RED SEA LINE COASTING MAIL SERVICE.

div.p: Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinan, Yambo and Jeddah,continuing in alternate weeks to PORT SUDAN, Suakim, Massowah, Hondeidah and Aden.
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG, wekkly from ANTWERP ; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTEERDAM AND HAMBURG.Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyances of cotton, ets from Alexandria cia Rotterdam and Hamburg to Gerrman manufacturing towns.
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
July 14 S.S. Athos from Hamburg.
July 24S.S. Andros from Hamburg bound for Rotterdam and Hamburg.
S.S. Chios from Antwerp now in port discharging.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Menepthah now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, 2nd July, to be followed by S.S. Khephres
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo.
For particulars apply to R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
SALOON FARE £12. Special Summer season rates £10 Port Said to Marseilles £7
S.S. MANDALAY 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 22nd July for Malta, Marseilles, & Devon.
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave ALEXANDRIA about 26th July for Dover.
S.S. AVA 7100 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 20th August for London
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 13 days.
The Saloon accommodation is anndships, ard tho vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light, and have all the latest improvements.
For further information apply to the Company's Agents.
WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Cunard Line.
div.p: Royal Mail Steamers from Liverpool to New York and Boston every Saturday and Tuesday.
Regular Twin Screw Sailings at short intervals from Trieste, Fiume and Naples to New-York.
Through tickets from Egypt delivered by Messrs. Rodacanachi & Co., Alexandria, General Agents ; Nicolas Kirzis, Cairo; R. Broadbent, Port Said, Agents. 19-1-907

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Asia Minor S.S. Co. Ltd. Best route to Cyprus, frequent sailings.
div.p: Passengers leave Cairo by noon train, steamer sails 5 p.m. Until further notice specially low 1st Class rates will be charged, Alexandria-Limassol £2. Alexandria-Larnaca or Famagusta £2.10. Fare for round trip (6 days) £4.10s.

Coupons entitling holders to passage to and from Cyprus, and a stay at the Mount Olympus Hotel, Troodos, can be purchased at the Company's office, 3 St. Mark-St., Alexandria, or from Thos Cook &Son (Egypt) Ltd. Cairo.

div.head: Service Maritime Roumain
div.p: 16 Rue Sesostris 16

Par suite de la quarantaine de 48 houres imposée par la Turquie aux provenances d'Egypte les paquebots-poste du Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandrie chaque quinzaine le Mercredi à 4 heures de l'après midi. Au cas où cette quarantaine serait réduite à 24 heures seulement les départs auront lieu le Jeudi à 4 p.m.
Alexandrie, le 25 Juin 1907.
For particulars apply to the Agents: OTTO STERZINC, Opera Square, CAIRO. W. H. MULLER & Co., Sesostris-st., ALEXANDRIA
Messrs. THOS. COOK & Son (Egypt) Ltd., are authorized to sell tickets in CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA. 20-10-06

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service 22 Febr.; 7, 23 March ; 4, 23 April ; 8 May ; 8 June.

div.head: Friday, JULY 26, 1907.
div.p: MISS CORELLI ON MAN.

"To put it bluntly and plainly," writes Miss Marie Corelli in the "Introductory Note” to her new book, "Delicia” (Constable), "a great majority of the men of the present day want women to keep them. It is these very men," she adds, "who at their clubs, or any other places where they can give themselves sublime airs of independence, frequently express regret in grandiloquent terms that there should be any women who want to be clever.' Such women | are always ‘unsexed.”

"This word 'unsexed,' ' Miss Corelli continnes, “is always cast at brilliant women by every little halfpenny ragamuffin of the Press that can get a newspaper corner in which to hide himself for the convenience of throwing stones. The woman who paints a great picture is 'unsexed'; the woman who writes a great book is 'unsexed'; in faet, whatever woman does that is higher and more ambitious than the mere act of flinging herself down at the feet of man and allowing him to walk over her, makes her in man's opinion unworthy of his consideration as woman."

"What," Miss Corelli asks, "are the occupations man graciously permits to woman without affronting her by this opprobious epithet. He is chiefly willing to see her on the stage. And he generally prefers the music hall stage as the best one fitted to her poor' abilities. It is no particular 'fun' to him to see her rise to the histrionic height of a Rachelor a Sarah Bernhardt. Nor does the exquisite grace of the finished 'comedienne' delight him entirely. No ! Neither the height of tragedy nor comedy in the woman on the stage really satisfy men so | much as the happy medium-the particular 'no-man's-land' of art, where nothing is demanded of her but-body and grin. A beantiful | body, trained to walk and look well--an affable grin, expanding at the sight of champagne and other mundane delicacies--these are all that is necessary.

"Now, if this beautiful body be well-nigh stripped to man's gaze night after night on the boards, he will never call the woman who so exposes herself 'unsexed, nor will he apply the word to her if she drinks too much wine and brandy. But if another woman, with quite AS beautiful a body, instead of exhibiting | herself half nude on the music hall stage, prefers to keep her woman's modesty, and execute some great work of art which shall be | as good and even better than anything man can accomplish, she will be dubbed 'unsexed instantly.
"I ask-Why is it that man elects to compass woman's degradation rather than hec uplifting and sanctification ?"

Miss Corelli alludes to "a certain individual, looked upon with a considerable amount of respect by the titled and monied classes, who married a bright little woman for her money, and since then has made her life an hourly misery." Miss Corelli also speaks of the miserable position voluntarily held by certain 'noblemen' who, because they have placed themselves in the unnatural and unbecoming condition of owing everything to their wives' money, permit those wives to play fast and | loose with their honour and good name, and apparently shut their eyes to the shameless infidelities which make them the by-word and contempt of all self-respecting 'commoners.'

"It would be a wholesome and refreshing stimulus to society,” she adds, "if such 'blueblooded lacqueys could awake to the fact that manbood is better than money, and would by their own free will and choice go out to hard | labour in the goldfields or elsewhere and earn their own livelihood bravely and independently, instead of lounging and frittering their days away, the silent and inactive spectators of | their wives' open and wanton degradation."

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Council of Ministers adjourned their meeting of yesterday, there being no business submitted.
The pupils of Daoud Salama School at Zasizin, have sent their eighth subscription for the New Egyptian University.
Arrivals from Bahrein are subjected to 48 hours observation in a lazaret of the Ottoman Empire and to disinfection and deratisation.
Saint Mustafa Nuzimeh, from Shibrazinji, was hung yesterday morning at Tantah prison, un conviction of having shot a woman, named Vateessa Bint Omar, on the 26th March last.
Today's plague bulletin reports 1 new case at Alexandria, that of a Greek baker, of Souk Tabakhin. Eight cases are under treatment in Alexanılria, half of which are Europeans.

The Alexandria Court of Assizes has condemned to death Aly El Senoussi convicted of murdering his sister on the 8th of April last. The girl, it will be remembered, was shot by Senoussii for having married against his will.

The Municipality of Alexandria has allotted a sum of £1,500 for the transfer of the statue of the late Mohamed Aly Pasha from its present position in the centre of the square to lis the new northern square close to the new quay.

Aly Hassan Kabab has been sentenced to three months' hard labour for having stolen P.T. 522 from a passenger at Cairo station. Aly Abdel Nebi has been condemned to a similar sentence for forging a Customs certificate.

The designs on which the sacred carpet is to be modelled have been submitted to the an Ministry of Finance which has given its approval. The making of the carpet will necessitate the employment of 500 okes of silk, of which 200 for the chain will be of the quality called aksira and 300 of Italian silk for the me weft.

The report of the Alexandria Municipality shows that during last year there was a remarkable falling off in the number of births belonging to members of the Church of England at Alexandria. The average number of births registered at the Anglican Church in Alexandria during the three years 1903-4-5 was 24 per annum. Last year, however, the total fell to 14. The members of the Scotch Church here improved on their average, which during these three years was 9 births per annum. Last year the Scotch births amounted to 12.

About five o'clock yesterday morning a house in the thickly populated quarter of Manasra at Cairo consisting of three storeys, and occupied by working people and their families, collapsed, and buried under its ruins many of the sleeping inhabitants. Rescue was speedily to hand and excellent work was done by the police and by the fire brigade, and it was not long before most of the bodies were recovered, though regrettably two deaths are recorded, while three persons have been more or less severely injured. At four o'clock yesterday afternoon the last body was recovered, life being extinct.

CASINO SAN STEFANO.
Le grand festival Wagner qui devait avoir lieu au Casino dimanche matin, est renvoyé vu l'indisposition de quelques artistes, à dimanche le 4 août.

Le concert d'hier au Casino avait attiré, comme il était à prévoir, une foule énorme. La terrasse suffisait à peine pour contenir toute l'élégance accourue pour applaudir ces artistes sympathiques dont la valeur est déjà connue de tous.
Aujourd'hui après-midi, grand bal d'enfants dans la salle des fêtes.
he had Decka

The Papayanni liner "City of Khios," sailed last night with 5006 bales of cotton for Liverpool

div.head: MANCHESTER AND CAIRO.
UNSATISFACTORY OUTLOOK
(Gazette's Special Service.)
div.p: LONDON, Friday.

'There are some signs which render it probable that the settlement of the trade difficulties, which were recently reported to exist owing to the troubles in which some Cairo firms found themselves, is likely to fall through. There was a meeting yesterday at Manchester to consider the policy that should be followed at the present juncture. The practical results of the meeting were unsatisfactory, as it is found to be a difficult business to bring the various parties interested into line.
GOLD IN SINAI.

In Egypt proper between the 22nd and 28th parallels of north latitude gold is now known to be widely distributed in both the older sedimentary and plutonic rocks, and more especially in the neighbourhood of, or actually in the less acid granites (hornblende granites), quartzdiorites, and diorites which often appear to form well-defined zones, near the junction of the granites with the ancient sedimentaries. As rocks of the last named type are largely developed in Eastern Sinai, the report on that part of Egypt, which has just been issued by the Survey Department, contains an interesting account of their distribution, and may prove of material aid to the prospector.

In many cases despite the large number of ancient workings, it has been most difficult to obtain even traces of gold at the surface, but deeper excavations have led to the finding of rich one bodies in some of the Egyptian mines. The want of superficial deposits is largely accounted for by the removal of the outcrops and weathered portions of auriferous bodies by the ancients, and in any case patient search and study of the various formations has been necessary to locate the old shutes ; such work does not come within the functions of a rapid geological survey, whose object must be to lay a wide general foundation on which more detailed research may be based.
Summarizing with regard to the occurrence of gold in Sinai it may be stated :--
1. That the similarity of the formations to those of the Eastern Deserts of Egypt is a hopeful indication that auriferous deposits will occur.
2. Only a systematic search by prospectors can prove the existence or non-existence of gold.
3. The quartz region near the foot of Gebel Abu Mesud may be indicated as one of the most likely spots at which to commence such an exploration.
From time to time expeditions have been made by various exploring parties into the Sinai Peninsula, but unfortunately but little of their data has been published.

div.head: MR. MONTAGUE SUMMERS ON EGYPTIAN STABILITY.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, I notice a paragraph in your issue of yesterday's date under the above heading in which the astounding statement is made that 120,000 tourists had visited Egypt last winter season, and had spent in his (Mr. Summers) estimation 18 millions sterling !! Taking all the hotels in Egypt, including Alexandria, Port Said, Cairo, Luxor, and Assouan, that cater for the tourist trade, a total of five thousand beds would be a very liberal estimate, and taking that each one of these beds was occupied for 100 nights during the season, also a liberal estimate, we would have a total of 500,000 beds occupied for one night each, or if you' give each tourist an average stay of 25 days we would have a total number of 20,000 tourists ; half that number instead of 120,000 is probably the correct figure. Again if you allow for each tourist and expenditure of two "pounds per day, the above calculation would amount to one million sterling instead of eighteen millions. I once heard a native proverb which roughly translated says "a hungry man dreams of loaves of bread". Mr. Montague Summers, if correctly reported, must have surely been indulging in a summer's daydream.
Yours faithfully
Yousef.
Cairo, July 25.
[We believe that the total number of first class passengers, which almost entirely include the tourist class, who landed in Egypt last season, did not exceed 12,000. Ed. E.G.)

div.head: OKAPI IN THE SUDAN
div.p: A note in the "Bulletin," of the Paris Museum, indicates that Captain (now Colonel) Marchand, of Fashoda fame, was the first European to see that interesting African ani. mal, the Okapi, alive. Some extracts are given from the journal kept by Captain Marchand on his expedition from the Congo to Fashoda. From these it appears that on the southern watershed of the Bahr-el-Ghazal, Marchand saw in a herd of antelopes a creature such as he had never seen before. It had a giraffe-like Deck and horns, the body was reddish brown in colour, while the limbs and hind-quarters were striped. This was in 1898. From the description, Professor Menegaux, who writes the note, is convinced that the unknown creature was the Okapi, which was thus seen for the first time in the flesh by a European.

div.head: PROSPECTS OF THE FLOOD.
div.p: During the last two or three days a rise of about one metre has taken place in the level of the Atbara River. This rise has been sustained and may possibly improve the levels generally. The flood, however, up to now considered as a whole seems so far as can be judged up to the present date, to be some a what late in its coming. What has arrived is below the average. This slight lateness of the flood will not affect the cotton crop or the watering of the sharaki lands, as the irrigation of these cultivations are proceeding in a satisfactory manner from the good supplies of water sent down by the Assouan Reservoir.

The critical period may be said to be the first 10 days of August, as the volume of the flood depends on the level attained by the Blue Nile at say, Roseires, being maintained for sufficient time in August. In 1903 the river on August 12 rose to & gauge reading of 20-8 metres and then fell slowly throughout the month. In 1904 it rose to 20-5 metres on July 31, then tell abruptly, 18-5 metres being mean for August in that year. On the ground of this and other information the prediction was made last year at the beginning of August that the Hood would be near the average, and that no grounds existed for expecting that it would exceed it to any extent. In the case of last year's flood, the general character of this period of six weeks 1 July 15 August was that the supply, which was below the average at first, improved rapidly towards the end.

Last year the Atbara at Khashm el Girba rose markedly at the end of July and the early part of August, so that at Wadi Halfa the level reached the mean of the 15 years 1890-1904 in August, but did not exceed it until the end of the month.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
THE NEW STEAMER.
div.p: The latest addition to the fleet of the Khedivial Company is the Union Liner, "Pretoria, and has been despatched to Newcastle-on"Tyne to the firm of Swan, Hunter, Wigham, Richardson and Company Limited, of Wallsendon-Tyne, who built the S.S. "Osmanieh.” The Pretoria" is to be entirely refitted to suit the exigencies of the trade of the Khediyial Mail Line and will be ready to leave England for Alexandria in five weeks time. She is 350 feet Hong and 41 feet wide. She has accommodation for 150 first class passengers. She has triple expansion engines and was originally built by William Denny and Brothers, of Dumbarton. She has a register tonnage of 3,303 and carries 5,200 tons of cargo.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MAIL S.S. CO.
div.p: Applications have been made to the Stock Exchange Committee to appoint & special settling day in and to grant a quotation to : Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, 40,000 Deferred Shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 60,001 to 100,000 (special application), and 40,000 Ordinary Shares of £10 each, fully paid Nos. 1 to 40,000.

div.head: DAMASCUS-BEYROUT LINE.
div.p: The Turkish Government during next month will dispose of a collection of Government stamps numbering 17,000,000. The collection contains specimens of current stamps of the realm, and also specimens which are valuable from a collector's point of view. There are also & number of Eastern Roumelian stamps. The sale will be effected by tender. Each Turkish Embassy and Legation is supplied with albums containing specimens of the stamps, and also copies of the conditions of sale, the latter being in the course of translation from Turkish. The proceeds of the sale are to form a nucleus for the building fund of the new railway to be constructed between Damascus and Beyrout. It is understood that a number of stamp connoisseurs have already inspected the collection. Particulars may be obtained at the Turkish Embassy.

div.head: A SYRIAN DRAGOMAN.
div.p: Said Kalil Haick, a young Syrian dragoman, just arrived in New York has announced that he was engaged to marry Miss Elsie Ellwood, danghter of Mr. W. L Ellwood and granddaughter of Colonel Isaac L. Ellwood, of| Dekalb, Ill. Colonel Ellwood, as a partner of Mr. John W. Gates, made many millions of dollars in the steel and wire business. Suid Haick is interested with Mr. Homer Davenport in the importation of Arabian horses at Dekalb. Mr. E. Perry Ellwood, son of Colonel Ellwood, said no Miss Elsie Ellwood he knew was engaged, and that he knew nothing of any contemplated marriage of any granddaughter of Colonel Isaac Ellwood.

Said Haick said; "I became acquainted with Miss Ellwood while acting as dragoman of her party in the desert and came to New York on the same ship with her and her mother." When asked when the ceremony would be performed, the Syrian grew vague.

PUBLIC HEALTH OF ALEXANDRIA.

One of the most interesting chapters, and probably the most instructive to the general public, of the Municipality report for 1906 is. that of Dr. Gotsoblich dealing with the sanitary service of the Municipality. Every section with which Dr. Gotschlich deals is full of interest and, therefore, we will not attempt to deal with his report in one issue, to do which would require too much generalisation to do justice to so important a branch of the Municipal Administration.

THE POPULATION.-Dr. Gotschlich first gives a few details of the population of Alexandria, which, he estimates, was on July, 1, 1906, 400,159, of which 332,586 were native inhabitants, and 67,566 foreigners.

He points out, however, that these figures cannot be vouched for as accurate, they being based upon the census of 1897 and the calculation of the increase in population being proportional to the increase of birth rate, but the great difficulty in ascertaining with accuracy the number of births must be remembered, there being no law compelling Europeans to register. It can be taken for granted, however, that the figure given is the minimum. Though in all probability the birth rate has a tendency to decrease, there is every indication that immigration has greatly increased. Upon sach bases Dr. Gotschlich Estimates that the death rate, instead of being 29.2%, as by the figures adopted, is probably 28.7%.

BIRTHS. During 1906, 13,937 native births were registered, as compared with the average of 12,743 for the years 1901 to 1905. Of these 13,641 were Mohamedans and 896 natives of other religions. According to the register of baptisms, however, the births of non-Mohamedans totalled 1,083, so that at least 17% were not made known to the sanitary authorities. Of births of foreigners only 668 were declared, while the baptism registries give a total of 1,571.

DEATHS. The deaths during 1906 totalled 11,683, of which 10,755 were natives, and the average death rate for the last decade is given as 31.2 %, while the average from 1901 to 1906 is 29:6 %. The highest figure during this latter period is registered for 1902 when the cholera epidemic largely accounted for a death rate of 34.3 %. In 1906 the actual number of deaths among adults was normal and it has been almost constant since 1901 ; and seeing that it is the adult population and not the infant population, owing to immigration, which is increasing, the death rate among adults is decreasing and therefore it may be assumed that the sanitary | conditions are improving. The death rate among native infants is almost 66 % and among foreign infants it is only 83% The number of deaths before the age of one year WAS 4,006 native and 193 European, with respective averages during the last five years of 3,630 and 183. From one to five years old the figures are 2,667 (average 2,552) natives, and 105 (average 127) Europeans.

INFECTIOUS DISEASES. — During 1906 there were in all 97 cases of plague recorded, 62 of which (64%) terminated fatally, but of these 62 only 7 were Europeans, among whom 18 cases were declared. 186 cases of diphtheria were notified and of these 94 (51%) died : practically 50% of the cases were natives, but among them the mortality was far heavier in in proportion, 63 out of 92 being fatal cases. of the 132 typhoid fever cases notified 64 | were Europeans, 59 Egyptians, and 9 Ottoman subjects, the deaths being respectively 31, 51, and 7. The death rate from typhoid, therefore, among Europeans was about 50% | while among the natives it was almost 100%. 92 cases of small-pox were notified, of which 36 terminated fatally. There were 631 deaths from tuberculosis among the natives and 83 Europeans died from this disease.
On the subject of infectious diseases Dr. Gotschlich says:

It is satisfactory to note that the frequency of infectious diseases has diminished during 1906 very remarkably, if one compares the figures of deaths for that year with those of 19 3 to 19' 5. Diphtheria alone shows a slight increase, though without reaching the level of 1905, while all the others show a considerable decrease."
For 1907, however, we shall most certainly see higher figures both as regards the plague and small-pox.

The figures for hydrophobia are very interesting and it is notable that last year no death from this fatal disease was recorded. In 1905 there were 19 mad animals, 28 people bitten, and 2 deaths; in 1903 there were 16 mad animals, 36 people bitten, and 4 deaths; and 111906 there were 4 mad animals, 4 persons bitten, and no deaths.

div.head: ACROSS THE SAHARA.
div.p: The Paris newspapers report that Captain Arnaud, of the Colonial Infantry, has succeeded in marching from Algiers to Kotonu, on the coast of Dahomey, due south of Algeria, in 127 days.
He covered a distance of 8120 miles, including over 700 miles over a new ronte. The expedition met with no opposition.-Reuter.
With this may be compared the 1700 miles joumey last autumn from Tripoli across the
Eastern Sahara to Lake Chad of Mr. Vischer,
the British resident at Kuka, on Lake Chad.

His progress was much slower, as he took about 460 days over the 1700 miles, as against the Frenchman's 127 days for 3120 miles ; but it must be remembered that Mr. Vischer was a civilian, and travelled with an ordinary caravan, which was attacked by Maregs.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA.
THE MAKING OF BYE-LAWS.
BY R. WILLIAMS F.R I B.A.
div.p: In the making of laws or bye-laws, any regulation which primarily should tend to har monize the varied amenities of life, the greatest care is needed, lest by any chance, legislators, national or local, should by their law or regulation making, play into the hands of selfishness and greed. In all laws and bye-laws there must be room for the foll play of honest discretion and, above all, of equity.

As an illustration of what is meant above, let us take the question of the foundation of a wall which abuts a neighbour's land. That is to say, a proprietor desires to build upon bis boundary. Now, it is a well known fact (not a mere theory of the axiom) that unless a wall has a foundation, considerably broader than the breadth or thickness of the superincumbent wall, it will be unsafe. But in order that the proprietor should be able to realise, without detriment to his neighbour, the full benefit of his land he must be allowed to build the projecting part of his foundation (below the surface of the ground) upon his neighbour's land. This can be done without harm to the neighbour, but the refusal to allow this accomodation can be, as pointed out already, harmful to the proprietor who wants build.

Under the London Building Act, all that is required is a notice to the adjoining owner that that proprietor is going to build and will put footings on the adjoining owner's land. This is only reasonable. But strange as it may seem here in Egypt, where long before the days of Herodotus (who noticed the aberration) it is still the custom to do things inversely. The Oairo Tanzim, SO my builder informs me, refused to allow him to put the footings of a wall he was building at Port Said on the land of the adjoining owner. This is, I am told, a Tanzim regulation. A regulation, be it understood, calculated to make of a new building a dangerous structure. Herein is another hint to the Alexandria bye-law makers.

Take another case. A case where preeminently equity should play the more prominent part. A manufacturer having established a business, which, for between forty and fifty years he has honourably conducted and to the benefit of Egypt and of Egyptians, finds himself in this late day, being overreached by a neighbour who, presuming upon bis knowledge that a building roksa or permit bad not been obtained by the manufacturer, proceeded to build some cottages on land near by and to promptly object to the proximity of workshop premises ! The neglect to obtain a roksa by the manufacturer can well be understood as he was established before the days of modern roksas. But what would be the result, supposing the object neighbour should gain his point. He will be able to buy the land deserted by the workshops at a cheap rate.

The case of the footings can be dealt with effectively in a bye-law, but the latter case is one (and many similar cases may arise, for selfishness and greed often goes to inordinate | lengths) which requires the utmost wisdom, and can only be decided by the universal law which Emerson called “the law of give and take" but which was better said by another teacher in the words, "Do unto others as ye would that others should do unto you."

Building laws are the result of compromise between conflicting causes. On the one hand our experience of trade and of life generally make certain demands on space, construction and sanitary arrangement; and on the other hand there is the question of cost, value of land and return on capital outlay. These considerations are in conflict, consequently the resulting laws always fall short of the true ideal. It is permissible to say that did we but realise the highest ideals with regard to our lives, laws would not be required.

Ancient Rome had its building laws as Vitruvius tells us, yet in the days of Augustus there was a crowding of tall buildings in narrow streets and a crowding of people within the buildings, accompanied by the resulting insanitation and disease.
The London building and health laws are among the most comprehensive of all such laws, yet crowding is rampant.

In the making of building laws, Alexandria | has a special advantage. Its Municipality can profit by the failures and experience of other cities, but while we recognise this, we must not forget that Alexandria is beset with other than the usual set of difficulties. The Capitulations present no small hindrance to the proper working of a sanitary and building code. Yet we may well suppose that for the benefit of the city in which they (some of them) make their fortunes and occasionally lose them, the beneficiaries by the Capitulations will surely brush aside all difficulties on that hend, and give to the Municipality 'a free hand in the making of laws for the health and safety and shall we say, beauty, of the town.
The essentials of the necessary bye-laws may be enumerated as follows -
1. The laying out of streets and of rainage, and of sewerage.
2. Naming streets.
3. Open spaces.
4. Construction.
5. Dangerous structures.
6. Temporary structures.
7. Dangerous businesses and factories
8. Duties of superintending architect, chief engineer and building inspectors
9. Procedure as to building notices.

In my next paper I shall deal with the first three points, with especial reference to the voluminous and exhaustive report of the Royal Comission on London Traffic, a work from which the Municipality of Alexandria may gather many useful hints.
(To be continued).
Coles Pasha has returned to Cairo from his tour of inspection of the Lower Egypt provincial prisons
We are glad to learn of the completo recovery of Mr. de Reffye.

Mr. James Currie, Dicector of Public Instruction in the Sudan will arrive Sunday that in Cairo, to recruit 10 teachers of English and Mathematics for the Sudan. 60 candidates have already applied for 8 vacant posts. The teachers will be of Egyptian nationality.

The following were among those who left for Constantinople yesterday by the Khedivial Mail S.S. "Kahira" Hussein Pasha Boucbdi, Mr. S. Varilass, Mrs. Cahorean, Mr, and Mrs.. Hassan Bey Zayed, Baroness Schilling Me Jeromides, Mrs. G. Sabet Bey, Ibrahim Boy Hacky, Osinan Bey Aly.
Among those leaving for Europe to-day by the M.M. mail boat are Abani Pasha, Mt. Maspero, 5 and Abdallah Bey Azoury.

div.head: THE “TIMES" AND MR BLUNT
IS HE A MINOR POET
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Blunts recent book, on Egypt has led to a dicussion in the "Athenaeum" of: the rights and responsibilities of the historian and to certain criticisms in the Times" and “Punch” which have called down the Wrath of the "Academy." This paper, in its issue of July 6, says :-"The Times” has no more right to call Mr. Blunt a minor poet then it i has to call Byron & minor poet, less right indeed. It was the "Times" I understand which when 'In Memoriam' was anonymously published, referred to it as this touching -poem, evidently the work of the widow o n military man,' and it will be the "Times undoubtedly who, if and when a new Keata arises in the land, will tell him to go back to his gallipots. "IL," adds the writer, "the "Times" has not the sense to see that Mr. Blant is not a 'minor poet, it might at least appreciate that he is probably one of the greatest masters of English prose that has appeared in the last hundred years."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui à 11x. jeans shot
div.p: Sac m es sloosha La tenue du marché est redevenue ce qu'elleza était au début de la semaine, c'est dire femmes et en hausse. Un aspectitres anima gener de règner dans la corbeille, et is l'on peutice discnter l'importance des affaires, i b'onde meure pas moins acqnis que de petites operaci tions, en assez grand nombre, ont apprêtress effectuées. Les cris : où sont les vendeurs font de nouveau retenti. Le fait est que depuis 1 quelque temps acheteurs et vendeurs simblenti jouer à cache-cache et dès que les ne tont la voir le bout de l'oreille les entre disparatament Ce sont les acheteorg qui ont eg ce matin le haut du payéquoi tient ce revirement, c'est ce qu'il est difficile de préciser: 'su dioodverty à l'exagération de la baisse, au soutien deel Londres Peut-être oes raisons se sontellega combinées pour influencer notre marché. Odol qu'il en soit, la cote bénéfice d'ime avance presque générale.
